text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 5.21.1 updated to include internal controls under Program Scope and Objectives.
IRM 5.21.1.2 updated to clarify that U.S. Possessions are deﬁned as a domestic
IRM 5.21.1, dated October 31, 2013, is superseded.
Revenue officers in SB/SE Field Collection (FC)
Table of Contents
) Purpose. This IRM provides speciﬁc procedural guidance for international revenue officers. These procedures may also have applications that and revenue officers may ﬁnd useful. (
) Audience. The audience is revenue officers in Small (SB/SE) Field Collection. (
) Policy Owner. The Director of Collection Policy is responsible for issuing policy for the International program. (
) Program Owner. The program owner is Collection Policy, Global Strategic Compliance, an organization within SB/SE Division. (
) Primary Stakeholders. The primary stakeholder is SB/SE Collection. (
) Program Goals. The goal of this IRM is to provide fundamental knowledge and procedural guidance for working international cases. (

) This IRM section deﬁnes matters that speciﬁcally relate to international tion issues. In today’s global economy, there are an increasing number of taxpayers who travel and work overseas. United States taxpayers, the U.S., and U.S. businesses are becoming more and more involved in national transactions. The U.S. is one of a very few countries in the world taxes its citizens and residents on their worldwide income. The role of an national revenue officer is very important in ensuring taxpayer compliance the tax laws and reducing the tax gap. (
) Congress has delegated to the IRS the responsibility of administering the laws, known as the Internal Revenue Code, found in Title
of the United States Code. Congress enacts these tax laws, and the IRS enforces them. (
) The Director, Collection Policy, is the executive responsible for the policy procedures to be employed by Collection personnel. (
) Field Collection Group Managers and Territory Managers are responsible ensuring the guidance and procedures described in this IRM are complied with. (

) Program Reports: a. Director, Field Collection Report - This monthly report encompasses all Field Collection including International and provides measures on the formance of Field Collection. b. International Territory Report - This monthly report provides measures the performance of the International territory. (

) Reviews: a. Collection Policy will conduct ad hoc International program reviews as necessary to verify compliance with IRM requirements and to address Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration/U.S. Government countability Office ﬁndings. b. Case reviews are conducted by Group Managers to ensure with this IRM. (

5.21 International and Insular Issues
Acronym Deﬁnition ATAT Abusive Tax Avoidance Transac- tion ICS Integrated Collection System POA Power of Attorney SB/SE Small Business/Self-Employed TECS Treasury Enforcement Communi- cation System
a. See IRM
through
for additional information on international collection issues. b. See IRM Part
for additional information on general collection issues such as courtesy investigations, international currently not collectible closing code
, Treasury Enforcement Communication System (TECS), initial contact, and special rules on mailing correspondence.

) An international case is a taxpayer or business having a current address outside the U.S. The primary factor that determines an international case is the address of the taxpayer. A foreign (international) address is any address that is not in one of the
states, District of Columbia or U.S. Possessions. All U.S. Possessions are considered domestic.

) Although the address of the taxpayer or business is a key factor, it is not the only factor in determining if the case is an international case. Usually, if the taxpayer has a domestic address, the case is assigned to a domestic collec- tion group. However, there are exceptions where the case may have a domestic address but the case is an international case.
The following are examples of an international case where the taxpayer has a

A taxpayer resides abroad but uses his power of attorney’s (POA) domestic address as his official address. This is usually the case in countries where the mail system is unreliable. The taxpayer uses his POA’s domestic address to ensure that he receives his mail from the Internal Revenue Service.

) More and more cases are identiﬁed as abusive tax avoidance transactions (ATAT) cases with the promotion of abusive schemes by taxpayers and promoters, and these cases are making their way into revenue officers’ tories. The process of determining the difference between an ATAT domestic case and an ATAT international case depends on the address of the taxpayer. (
) A taxpayer with a current international address involved in an abusive is an international ATAT case. a. See IRM
, Account Transfers to International, for more on transferring cases to international. (

) Generally, domestic ATAT cases: a. are identiﬁed through Issue Management Teams which identify preparers, and participants; b. are developed by Examination and other Operating Divisions and functions.
5.21.1.2.1 (10-19-2017) Difference Between Domestic ATAT and International ATAT Cases
a. are identiﬁed through Issue Management Teams which identify preparers, and participants; b. are developed by Examination and other Operating Divisions and functions.
Note: Coordination between international revenue officers and ATAT revenue officers is essential in identifying domestic and foreign assets, and can provide both functions with valuable information.
